The Project will yield a  wide range of benefits across different levels, 
including  the  macroeconomic  level,  the  sector  and  policy  levels,  the 
institutional  level,  and  the  investment  and  enterprise  levels.  The 
Project will stimulate the local economy, generate employment, create 
tax  revenues,  and  assist  in  the  transfer  of  modern  technologies  and 
business  practices  from  abroad  to  Afghanistan.  It  is  designed  to 
stimulate private business activity and attract foreign direct investment 
in  a  variety  of  sectors,  including,  but  not  limited  to,  manufacturing, 
agribusiness, banking, and smaller scale infrastructure projects.  
 
A key concern is that private investors and lenders will not be induced 
to finance transactions despite the risk mitigation offered by the AIGF 
and  other  risk  participants  such  as  MIGA  and  ADB.  The  main  risks 
relate  to  security,  policy,  and  business  risks,  for  which  mitigation 
measures have been put in place as applicable. Security continues to 
be  a  concern  for  investors,  and  if  the  security  situation  deteriorates 
significantly,  private  investors  may  choose  not  to  continue  with  plans 
to  invest  in  Afghanistan  despite  the  existence  of  the  Project.  Also, 
effective sanctioning, monitoring, and legal systems are just emerging, 
and  effective  contract  enforcement  has  yet  to  be  demonstrated. 
Another  risk  is  that  after  an  initially  good  start,  a  large  number  of 
claims  may  arise  due  to  a  breakdown  of  the  political  environment  or 
even  a  resumption  of  hostilities.  This  risk  will  be  mitigated  by  ADB’s 
and MIGA’s right to suspend the issuance of guarantees.

2. 
Importance  of  Private  Sector  Development  Recognized.  After  prolonged  civil  strife 
and  conflict,  Afghanistan's  infrastructure  and  industries  are  in  a  desolate  condition;  its  human 
resource  base  and  social  capital  are  severely  depleted,  and  public institutions  are  hindered by 
weak operational capacity. While the international community is exerting considerable efforts to 
support  Afghanistan’s  rebuilding  and  development,  available  official  flows  are  not  sufficient  to 
support  and  sustain  the  reconstruction  effort.  A  vibrant  private  sector  is necessary  to  generate 
employment and long-term economic growth for poverty reduction, and to realize tangible results 
from  further  prospects  of  lasting  peace.  The  importance  of  private  sector  development  is  also 
laid down in the country’s new constitution, which was adopted in December 2003.2 
 
3. 
Improvement in Investment Environment. The Government of Afghanistan has taken 
significant  steps  to  improve  the  institutional,  policy,  and  legal  environments  for  investment.  In 
October  2003,  the  Afghanistan  Investment  Support  Agency  (AISA)  was  created  as  a 
professional  body  within  the  framework  of  the  Ministry  of  Commerce  to  facilitate  and  promote 
investment  in  Afghanistan.  A  government  directive  created  AISA  as  a  “one  stop  shop  for 
investors”,  and  made  it  responsible  for  registering,  licensing,  and  promoting  all  investments  in 
Afghanistan. AISA aims to operate as a lean and efficient organization, with key staff possessing 
significant international business experience. As one of its first measures, AISA streamlined the 
registration process for new investments into Afghanistan from more than 28 steps, which took 
several  months  to  complete,  to  only  5  steps  that  can  be  completed  in  less  than  1  week.  In 
addition,  a  new  investment  law3  was  drafted  and  is  expected  to  be  enacted  shortly.  It  is 
considered  one  of  the  most  progressive  investment  laws  in  the  region,  allowing  full  foreign 
investment  in  virtually  all  sectors  of  the  economy.  There  are  no  restrictions  on  remittances  of 
profits  and,  in  case  of  investor  complaints,  international  dispute  settlement  is  provided.  In 
addition, an open trade regime has been introduced, including a tariff band with only four slabs 
and maximum tariff of only 16% and streamlined customs clearance. 
 
4. 
Financial  Sector  Reforms  Under  Way.  A  more  efficient  financial  sector  will  be  key  to 
Afghanistan’s private sector development, and important reforms have been undertaken over the 
past 18 months. In early 2003, a new currency was successfully introduced. Since then, a stable 
exchange  rate  regime  has  been  maintained,  and  inflation  has  been  kept  under  control.  To 
facilitate  an  efficient  financial  sector,  a  new  banking  law  was  enacted.  It  allows  banks  to  be 
100% foreign owned. Several international banks have already opened offices in Afghanistan to 
offer a wider range of financial services.

Private Sector Development is High on the Development Agenda. The Government 
has given high priority to private sector promotion in its development agenda. Early in 2002, a

assistance, human and social capital; (ii) physical reconstruction and natural resources, and (iii) 
private  sector  development.  In  the  NDF,  the  Government  expressed  a  strong  commitment  to 
develop a competitive export-oriented economy, to provide the engine of growth and instrument 
of social inclusion through the creation of business opportunities.

Eligible Investors and Investments. Eligible investors include individuals, corporations,

issued, targeting primarily at SMEs across a wide range of sectors (para. 10).

71.  Macro-Benefits.  On  the  macro-level,  the  Project  will  support  economic  growth  by 
stimulating the local economy through new investments. The new investments will have positive 
implications  for  the  labor  market  through  increased  and  sustainable  employment  opportunities, 
which  in  turn  will  contribute  to  poverty  reduction.  Increased  tax  revenues  as  a  result  of  higher 
economic  activity  can  also  lead  to  positive  fiscal  implications.  Moreover,  increased  FDI  has 
positive balance-of-payment implications and will support integration into the global marketplace. 
Importantly, by stimulating private sector development as an essential element for the country’s 
economic  progress  and  as  a  foundation  for  peace  and  stability,  the  Project  will  make  an 
important contribution to the ongoing rebuilding and reconstruction of Afghanistan. 
 
72. 
Sector  and  Policy  Benefits.  On  the  sector  level,  the  Project  will  support  industrial 
production  and  development  by  improving  productivity  in  manufacturing  and  services  across  a 
variety of industry sub-sectors. The Project will assist in the transfer of modern technologies and 
business  practices  to  Afghanistan.  The  increased  investment  will  further  yield  economic  spill-
overs  and  contribute  to  the  emergence  of  private  input  supply  and  output  marketing  channels 
and, by creating equal opportunities for all sectors in a nondiscriminatory manner, allow private 
markets to determine allocation for financing. Finally, it will enhance the credibility of Afghanistan 
as  an  investment  destination  with  an  open  and  transparent  business  climate  characterized  by 
the rule of law. As Afghanistan is emerging from a postconflict situation and undertaking a fresh 
start in many areas, this additional level of comfort will be particularly required to attract private 
sector investment early on.  
 
73. 
Institutional Benefits. Through parallel TA financing implemented by MIGA, the Project 
will support capacity building for key agencies involved in investment promotion, including AISA 
and the local chambers of commerce.

commercial  enterprises  establish  links  with  foreign  firms  in  order  to  restart  or  establish  their 
operations, through joint ventures;  upgrade production processes and product quality; facilitate 
access  to  financing  for  increased  investment;  and  import  critical  inputs  into  the  production 
process and economic activity.

will  contribute  to  poverty  reduction  and  indirectly  lead  to  improvement  in  a  range  of  other  social  and  economic

Poverty Analysis  

What type of poverty analysis is needed?  

Proposed Classification:   Other 

No poverty assessment has been prepared and no poverty partnership agreement (PPA) has been signed. Initiating 
and completing work on the preparation of a PPA will be synchronized with the preparation of a full country strategy

preparation of sector road maps, was initiated last year. 

Reliable  statistics  on  poverty  are  not  available  for  Afghanistan.  However,  various  estimates  place  at  60–80%  the 
proportion of the population living below the threshold of $1 a day or consuming less than the minimum requirement of 
the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) of 2,453 kilocalories a day per capita.  

The  average  life  expectancy  is  only  about  40  years;  nearly  two  thirds  of  adults,  and  four  fifths  of  adult  women  are 
illiterate; 70% of the population are malnourished; and in 1999 less than one third of Afghan children were enrolled in 
school. Particularly vulnerable are those without any source of food production, employment, or income. Nonmaterial 
poverty  as  reflected  in  physical  and  social  insecurity;  isolation;  marginalization;  alienation;  and  ethnic,  religious,  and 
gender discrimination pushes many Afghans further down the poverty ladder.  

No  systematic  study  has  been  done  on  the  factors  contributing  to  poverty  in  Afghanistan,  but  available  information 
suggests that poverty is associated with low economic growth and the collapse of income-generating and employment 
opportunities due to the long period of war and civil strife, particularly in rural areas. Other factors likely pertain to the 
distinctive features of the agro-ecological environment (e.g., frequent droughts), state of natural resource degradation, 
land  ownership  and  tenure,  loss  of  livestock  and  destruction  of  orchards,  access  to  water  and  agricultural  inputs, 
availability  of  off-farm  employment  opportunities,  refugee/displacement  status,  gender,  ethnicity,  household  status 
(e.g., with female head or not, educational attainment), and physical disability.
